case_vignette: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of the sudden appearance of a rash on her trunk that started 6 hours ago and subsequently spread to her extremities. Four days ago, she was taken to the emergency department because of a high fever and vomiting. She was treated with acetaminophen and discharged the next day. The fever persisted for several days and abated just prior to appearance of the rash. Physical examination shows a rose-colored, blanching, maculopapular rash, and postauricular lymphadenopathy.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly got a rash on my tummy six hours ago, and it has spread to my arms and legs.
How old is the patient experiencing the rash?
I am 15 months old.
Is the rash itchy or painful?
The rash doesn't hurt or itch.
Have you had any recent illnesses or fevers?
Yes, I had a high fever and was throwing up four days ago.
Has the patient recently been in contact with any ill individuals or known allergens?
I don't know, nobody told me about that.
Does the patient have any known allergies or a history of similar rashes?
I don't know about any allergies or if I've had rashes like this before.
Has the patient experienced any new foods, medications, or environmental changes prior to the rash appearing?
I can't say for sure, no one mentioned anything like that to me.
Is the rash accompanied by any other symptoms, such as cough, runny nose, or diarrhea?
I don't have a cough, runny nose, or diarrhea.
Is the rash localized to certain areas or is it widespread across the body?
The rash is on my trunk and it has spread to my arms and legs.
Are there any other symptoms present, like swelling of the limbs, joint pains, or changes in eating or drinking habits?
I have swollen glands behind my ears, but no swelling in my limbs, joint pain, or changes in how I eat or drink.
Have the patient's parents or caregivers noticed if the rash blanches (turns white) when pressed?
Yes, the rash turns white when you press on it.
Final Diagnosis: Roseola (also known as sixth disease or roseola infantum)
